title: Effect of HNO3 formation on N2O5 equilibrium

content.description: In the atmosphere, small water droplets are suspended in the air, forming an aerosol. <math alttext="N 2 O 5 gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> can form <math alttext="H N O 3 aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> under these conditions, as shown in reaction 2, represented below.
content.question: Reaction 2: <math alttext="N 2 O 5 gas plus H 2 O liquid reacts to produce 2 H N O 3 aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O(</mtext><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> Which of the following predicts the effect that the formation of <math alttext="H N O 3 aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> will have on the equilibrium shown in reaction 1, and why?

choices.label: The equilibrium of reaction 1 will shift toward the formation of more product, because <math alttext="N 2 O 5 gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is removed when it reacts to form <math alttext="H N O 3 aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The equilibrium of reaction 1 will shift toward the formation of more product, because <math alttext="H 2 O liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> acts as a catalyst for reaction 1.

The equilibrium of reaction 1 will shift toward the formation of more reactants, because the product <math alttext="N 2 O 5 gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is removed when it reacts to form <math alttext="H N O 3 aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The equilibrium of reaction 1 is not affected, because neither <math alttext="H 2 O liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> nor <math alttext="H N O 3 aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> are gases.

content.answer: The equilibrium of reaction 1 will shift toward the formation of more product, because <math alttext="N 2 O 5 gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is removed when it reacts to form <math alttext="H N O 3 aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 6.F: Explain the connection between experimental results and chemical concepts, processes, or theories.
